title-group.article-title: Spirostane saponins with a rearranged A/B ring system isolated from the rhizomes of Ophiopogon japonicus

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Spirostane saponins with a rearranged A/B ring system isolated from the rhizomes of
Ophiopogon japonicus

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Structure elucidation
Spirostane saponins
Cytotoxic activity
ABSTRACT

In this study, the popular food and medicinal herb
Ophiopogon japonicus
was investigated alongside a 70% ethanol extract of its rhizomes, revealing twenty-three steroidal glycosides with four undescribed steroidal saponins, named ophiopogonols A–D. Among them, ophiopogonols A–B are two unusual spirostanols with a rearranged A/B ring system (5/7/6/5/5/6 ring system) that have not previously been identified in plants. The chemical structures of all isolated steroidal glycosides were elucidated by comprehensive analysis through chemical methods, HRESIMS, and NMR spectroscopy. Further, putative biosynthetic pathways for ophiopogonols A–B were proposed. In addition, based on traditional applications of
O. japonicus
, cytotoxic effects of the isolates were evaluated using human large cell lung carcinoma cells (NCI–H460 cells). Sprengerinin C displayed a remarkable cytotoxic effect with IC 50 values of 2.1 ± 0.8 μM by inducing apoptosis and G2/M phase cycle arrest in the NCI–H460 cell line.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In this study, a series of Traditional Chinese Medicines (TCMs) rich in steroidal saponins were screened. Four undescribed steroidal saponins and nineteen known compounds were isolated and identified from the 70% ethanol extract of
O. japonicus
( Fig. 1 ). Notably, ophiopogonol A and ophiopogonol B, two spirostanols with rearranged A/B ring system, were obtained from plants for the first time. Furthermore, a putative biosynthetic pathway of the two unusual steroidal saponins and the cytotoxicity of the isolates are also described.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
Ophiopogonol C ( 3 ) displayed m / z 461.2921 [M-H] - (calcd. 461.2903 for C 27 H 41 O 6 ), as determined by HRESIMS analysis. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra ( Table 2 ) displayed four methyl groups [ δ H 0.66 (3H, d, J = 5.5 Hz, H 3 -27)/ δ C 17.7 ( CH 3 -27), δ H 0.99 (3H, s, H 3 -18)/ δ C 22.2 ( CH 3 -18), δ H 1.30 (3H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, H 3 -21)/ δ C 10.0 ( CH 3 -21), and δ H 1.10 (3H, s, H 3 -19)/ δ C 20.0 ( CH 3 -19)]; three hydroxyl groups [ δ H 5.85 (14-OH), 6.57 (17-OH) and 7.05 (12-OH)]; two quaternary groups [ δ C 88.8 (C-14) and 94.8 (C-17)]; three tertiary oxygenated carbons [ δ C 71.6 (C-3), 76.9 (C-12), 91.6 (C-16)]; and a distinctive ketal group at δ C 110.1 (C-22), indicating 3 possessed a Δ 5,6 -spirostanol skeleton with a –OH group at C-3, C-12, C-14, and C-17. Analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra demonstrated that compound 3 was in good agreement with the aglycone moiety of ophiopogonin R (
), except for discrepancies in carbon signals caused by glycosylation, whereby downfield shifts of 2.9 ppm for C-2 ( δ C 33.1) and 5 ppm for C-3 ( δ C 44.0), and an upfield shift of 6.1 ppm for C-4 ( δ C 44.0), were observed in
3 in
comparison to ophiopogonin R. The aforementioned deduction was confirmed by the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ). The 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum showing proton interactions of H-1/H 2 -2, H 2 -2/H-3, H-3/H 2 -4 and HMBC correlations from δ H 2.65 (H-4), 1.82 (H-1) to δ C 71.6 (C-3) established the presence of a hydroxyl group at C-3. In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 ), the key correlations from δ H 7.05 (12-OH) to δ C 29.2 (C-11), from δ H 5.85 (14-OH) to δ C 49.0 (C-13) and 88.8 (C-13), and from δ H 6.57 (17-OH) to δ C 19.7 (C-13), 91.6 (C-16), and 94.8 (C-17) indicated that the three hydroxyl groups were connected at C-12, C-14, and C-17, respectively. The NOE correlations ( Fig. 3 ) of H-8/H 3 -18, H-12/H 3 -18, 12-OH/H-9, H 3 -18/H-20, 17-OH/H 3 -21 and H-16/H 3 -21 indicated the 12 α , 14 α, and 17 α configurations of hydroxyl groups, β -orientation of H-20, and trans -trans ring junction of rings B, C, and D. The D/E cis and α -configuration of H-3 were deduced from correlations of H-1 β /H 3 -19, H-1 α /H-3, and H-1 α /H-9. Thus, compound 3 was confirmed to be 12-hydroxy ophiogenin.
a Measured at 400 MHz for 1 H NMR, 100 MHz for 13 C NMR.
b Measured at 600 MHz for 1 H NMR, 150 MHz for 13 C NMR.
c Signals overlapped.

sec.title: Orphanage

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b Measured at 600 MHz for 1 H NMR, 150 MHz for 13 C NMR.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: c Signals overlapped.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In summary, a chemical study of the rhizomes of
Ophiopogon japonicus
revealed four undescribed steroidal saponins ( 1–4 ), including the first example of steroids ( 1 and 2 ) with a rearranged A/B ring system from plants, and nineteen known steroidal glycosides ( 5–23 ). The biogenetic pathway of unusual steroids 1 and 2 was postulated based on bimolecular nucleophilic substitution. According to the traditional uses and new application as a treatment for lung diseases, all the isolates were tested for their cytotoxic effects against the NCI–H460 cell line, and sprengerinin C ( 19 ) exhibited a stronger cytotoxic effect than the positive drug cisplatin.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
4.2. Plant materials
sec.p:
The rhizomes of
Ophiopogon japonicus (Thunb.) Ker-Gawl. (Asparagaceae)
[the name
Ophiopogon japonicus
(L. f.) Ker-Gawl. ( Liliaceae ) was recorded in the Chinese Pharmacopeia for 2020] were acquired from Tianjin Tasly Plant Medicine Limited Liability Company ( Shaanxi , China ), and the raw materials were collected according to the Pharmacopeia standard in October (autumn), 2016. The herbs were authenticated by Professor Yingni Pan (School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University). The voucher sample (No.20161015) was preserved at the School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
O. japonicus
( 17.5 kg ) was refluxed three times (70% ethanol) for 2 h each. The crude extract ( 9.6 kg ) was obtained by recovering the ethanol solvent under reduced pressure, dissolved in methanol, fractioned with D101 macroporous adsorbent resin, and eluted with EtOH/H 2 O (0, 20%, 50%, 70%, and 90%) to obtain Fr 1–5, respectively. The Fr. 3 ( 52.2 g ) and Fr. 4 ( 33.8 g ) were chromatographically separated using a silica gel column to obtain 10 fractions (Fr. A1–A5 and Fr. B1–B5), respectively, with CH 2 Cl 2 /MeOH (100:0–0:1) as the solvent. Subsequently, each fraction was separated by column chromatography with ODS using MeOH/H 2 O (40%, 60%, 80% and 100%). Fr. B2-3 was purified by HPLC using MeOH/H 2 O (80: 20) to isolate compounds 1 ( 10.4 mg ) and 2 ( 6.1 mg ). Compounds 3 ( 8.4 mg ) and 4 ( 9.4 mg ) were separated under 75% MeOH/H 2 O condition from Fr. A5-2. At the same time, Fr. A5-2 was isolated by HPLC using MeOH/H 2 O (64: 36) to obtain compounds 8 ( 5.4 mg ), 14 ( 5.6 mg ), 16 ( 18.8 mg ), 17 ( 15.3 mg ), and 18 ( 15.5 mg ). Fr. B4 was chromatographed with HPLC method by using 85% MeOH/H 2 O to obtain compounds 6 ( 14.9 mg ) and 9 ( 79.9 mg ); the sub-fraction Fr. B5 was isolated by HPLC with 78% MeOH/H 2 O to obtain compounds 7 ( 12.1 mg ), 20 ( 21.1 mg ), 21 ( 10.3 mg ) and 22 ( 50.2 mg ). Through HPLC separation of Fr. B6 under 66% MeOH/H 2 O conditions, compounds 10 ( 42.3 mg ), 11 ( 5.5 mg ), 12 ( 3.2 mg ), 13 ( 84.7 mg ), 14 ( 5.6 mg ), 15 ( 14.4 mg ) were obtained, and compounds 5 ( 4.4 mg ), 19 ( 3.5 mg ), and 23 ( 7.5 mg ) were obtained from Fr. B8-2 under 82% MeOH/H 2 O conditions.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Cisplatin was used as positive control.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b IC: 50% cell viability concentration. (Mean ± SD of 3 tests).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Ophiopogonol A (1)
sec.p:
White needle crystals (MeOH); mp 165–167 ◦ C; [ α ]
D 20 = 17.9 ( c 0.10 CH 3 OH); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m / z 431.3172 [M+ H] + (calcd. 431.3161 for C 27 H 43 O 4 ).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Ophiopogonol B (2)
sec.p:
White needle crystals (MeOH); mp 165–167 ◦ C; [ α ]
D 20 = 32.1 ( c 0.10 CH 3 OH); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 429.3017 [M-H] - (calcd. 429.3005 for C 27 H 41 O 4 ).
4.3.3. Ophiopogonol C (3)

White needle crystals (MeOH); mp 255–257 ◦ C; [ α ]
D 20 = 61.9 ( c 0.20 CH 3 OH); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m / z 461.2921 [M-H] - (calcd. 461.2903 for C 27 H 41 O 6 ).
4.3.4. Ophiopogonol D (4)

White needle crystals (MeOH); mp 188–191 ◦ C; [ α ]
D 20 = 56.1 ( c 0.30 CH 3 OH); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m / z 431.3168 [M-H] - (calcd. 431.3161 for C 27 H 43 O 4 ).
4.4. Biological assay
4.4.1. Cell proliferation assays and morphological changes
4.4.2. Apoptosis detection and cell cycle analysis

sec.title: 4.4.3. Hoechst 33258 staining
sec.p:
Hoechst staining was performed to further investigate the morphological changes induced by sprengerinin C ( 19 ) in NCI–H460 cells. NCI–H460 cells were treated with sprengerinin C at a concentration of 1.0 μM, 2.0 μM, and 4.0 μM for 48 h. After treatment, 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS was used to fix cells for 30 min, and 10.0 μg/ml Hoechst 33258 was used to stain cells for 10 min. The cells were then viewed using UV fluorescence microscopy at 355 nm and 465 nm (
).

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112975.
